section.title: Determinants: Cofactor expansions
section.p: We begin by describing one formula for determinants. This definition may seem strange, and we will have to wait to see where it comes from and ho it is connected to invertibility and volumes. However, it is convenient for calculations and will be enough to kick off our study of the determinant.

We will build up this cofactor expansion from the ground up in a recursive procedure. Namely, this method will say how to compute the determinant for n\times n matrices, assuming we already know how to do so for (n-1)\times(n-1) matrices.

Let's start at the beginning. First, we require determinants for 1\times1 matrices. As discussed in the last section, the natural definition of the determinant in this case, which is correct one, is \det(a)=a. To give our general formula, we first need to give a little notation.

statement.p: Suppose that A is an n\times n matrix A.
The (i,j)-th minor, denoted A_{ij}, is the determinant of the (n-1)\times (n-1) matrix obtained from A by deleting the i-th row and the j-th column.
The (i,j)-th cofactor \ C_{ij} is defined in terms of the minor by C_{ij}=(-1)^{i+j}A_{ij}.

section.p: Using , we can describe our procedure for computing determinants as follows.

algorithm.title: Cofactor/Laplace expansion
algorithm.p:
To compute the determinant of a square matrix, do the following.
Choose any row or column of A.
For each element a_{ij} of this row or column, compute the associated cofactor C_{ij}.
Multiply each cofactor by the associated matrix entry a_{ij}.
Result: The sum of these products is \det A.

section.p: In formulas, this says that if we pick row i to "expand along," then the cofactor expansion formula is \det A=\sum_{j=1}^n a_{ij}C_{ij}, where in the sum the number i is fixed. Similarly, if we pick column j to expand along, then we obtain a formula \det A=\sum_{i=1}^n a_{ij}C_{ij}. Note that this gives 2n seemingly-different formulas, which all give the same number! We will why this is true later, and simply assume this for now.

Let's try this out for a general 2\times2 matrix A=\spalignmat{a,b;c,d}. Choosing the first row of A in Step 1 of the cofactor expansion algorithm (when we do this, we also say that we are expanding the determinant along the first row), we find that \det A=aC_{11}+bC_{12}=aA_{11}-bA_{12}. Now A_{11} is the determinant of the matrix obtained by deleting the first row and the first column of A as in the following picture:

This matrix is just the single-entry matrix \spalignmat{d}. Similarly, A_{12} is the determinant of \spalignmat{c}. As we have seen that the determinant of a 1\times1 matrix is just the number inside of it, the cofactor expansion in this case recovers the formula \det A=ad-bc from before.
Let's try the same thing on a slightly larger example.

statement.p: We find the determinant of A= \mat{2 1 3;-1 2 1;-2 2 3}. We make the somewhat arbitrary choice to expand along the first row. We compute the minors as A_{11} = \det\mat{2 1;2 3} \quad\quad A_{12}=\det\mat{-1 1;2 3} \quad\quad A_{13}=\det\mat{-1 2;-2 2}. Computing these 2\times 2 determinants, we have A_{11}=4,\quad\quad A_{12}=-1,\quad\quad A_{13}=2. By inserting signs, we find that the cofactors are C_{11}=A_{11}=4,\quad\quad C_{12}=-A_{12}=1,\quad\quad C_{13}=A_{13}=2. Thus, \det A=a_{11}C_{11}+a_{12}C_{12}+a_{13}C_{13} =2(4)+(1)+3(2)=15.

section.p: With this method, much larger determinants are also easy to compute, especially when there are lots of zeros in a row or column. Generally speaking, it is a good idea when computing an example to try to expand along a row or column with as many zeros as possible, or at least with the smallest entries possible.

Although this technique works reasonably quickly in most small examples, several important questions remain:
Where do these formulas come from?
How do we know that these numbers give the same answer regardless of which row or column we choose (that is, this method gives 2n different expressions for the same number attached to an n\times n matrix, which we claim are always all equal).
Why does this number have to do with invertibility?
